PARA.TAB: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Kerry Sibraa) took the chair at 2 p.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I refer to the government's budget of betrayal which is rapidly becoming a budget of humiliation. Is it not a fact that, as far as low income earners are concerned, by the time they get that miserable $3 a week rebate they will be being slugged an extra $3.50 a week for petrol for the average car, at least $3 a week for the average family as a result of sales tax increases and an extra $5 a week for cigarettes? What is fair about the continuing savage impact of this viciously regressive budget on those who are least able to afford it?

—I make the point at the outset that if Senator Alston or anyone else on the other side believes that there has been some betrayal in the steps that the government has taken, they always have the opportunity and the option of voting for the budget, which any decent minded or responsible opposition might be expected to do.

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Those opposite cannot have it both ways. They cannot express their hostility and distaste for everything in the budget and then think they can have the luxury of voting against it and creating an opportunity for others to do their work.

PARA.TAB: On the subject of equity issues, we have made it perfectly clear that this is not a regressive budget and never has been. The measures that have been taken in the last 24 hours have the effect of ensuring that any conceivable doubts that there might be on this subject have been well and truly alleviated. I refer to the increase from $100 to $150 so far as the low income earners rebate is concerned; so far as the modification of the petrol excise is concerned; and so far as the impact of the optometry and other measures are concerned.

It needs to be understood, as has often been said, that throughout the 1980s the government has improved the equity of the tax system through a number of measures which have been taken to broaden the tax base and to reduce tax avoidance. That equity has been very important so far as lower income earners are concerned. There will be 4.2 million taxpayers with incomes below $24,450 who will benefit from the introduction of the new tax rebate. This will mean that 130,000 taxpayers will have their tax liability eliminated altogether.

The tax cuts are just one element of a package of continuing reforms to assist Australian families. The package includes adjustments which have had less attention than they should have had because they are a very important contribution to the equity of this whole package. For example, adjustments to the family assistance system, including the introduction of the home child care allowance from September 1994, have made it a simpler system of greater benefit to low income earners. We have an age pension which over the course of the past 10 years has increased from 22.7 per cent of average weekly earnings to 25.5 per cent at present. These are the measures which we believe fully allow us to keep our heads held up so far as the equity of the budget is concerned in its impact on lower income earners.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I know that arithmetic has never been the minister's long suit, but he does not seem to have disputed the figures that I have put to him. Does it therefore follow that he takes the view that an additional $12 a week in imposts on low income earners, as a result of what is left of all the nasties to be compensated for by a rebate of $3 a week, is fair and reasonable and that these people should sleep soundly in their beds? Is one in four the minister's definition of equity?

—I do not take anything that Senator Alston says at face value, let alone the figures that he has just put to me today. I will examine the implications of what he says and get a response in more detail from the Treasurer about that. But our clear understanding is that the overall impact of the budget was not regressive, except perhaps in a very marginal way at some levels in its formulation. Certainly any lingering concerns there may have been of that kind have been well and truly eliminated as a result of the further changes that have been made.
—You are a disgrace.
—I am not going to tolerate unparliamentary language that is coming constantly from interjections.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Transport and Communications. I refer to the recent report on the progress of aviation reform published by the Bureau of Transport and Communications Economics. Can the minister advise the Senate what some of the major findings of this report were, especially in regard to better outcomes for the travelling public? In addition to the bureau's findings, can the minister advise whether there have been recent changes in the use of larger aircraft to service some long haul Australian domestic airline sectors?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —As to the last part of Senator Colston's question, the answer is yes. The bureau's report is very timely in a public policy sense in that it has provided a very comprehensive analysis of the results of the very significant changes in aviation policy that the government has brought about in the last few years. The bureau report noted that these reforms have been far reaching and it made the comment that they will still be felt by the industry at the turn of this century.

PARA.TAB: In terms of the impact of deregulation, the bureau found that greater freedom now exists in market entry; there is far more competition between incumbent domestic operators; the travelling public now has the benefit of lower than average air fares; domestic operators have improved their efficiency; and within the domestic market annualised net welfare gains of around $100 million per annum have been realised. More Australians and overseas tourists are flying in Australia today than ever before—around 18.6 million passengers a year to be precise. A small example of the significance of aviation reform was recently shown by the first departure of a Qantas Boeing 747 jumbo jet from the domestic terminal at Sydney airport. This month will see the inaugural international flight of Ansett from Australia to Bali, which is staging through my home city of Darwin.
The government's aviation policy is delivering major benefits to the travelling public, tourism and trade. I believe that the conclusion of the report is worth noting. It states:

ANSWER.PARA: There may still be a long haul before anyone is completely satisfied with the efficiency of our airline system or its contribution to Australia's competitiveness but, so far, we can judge that we are on target and on the right track.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer in the Senate, Senator Gareth Evans.
—Senator McMullan.

—Senator McMullan. I refer the minister to the government's budget of betrayal. Is it not the case that despite yesterday's backdown the budget still results in a situation where in excess of $3 billion in extra taxes will be levied? Could the minister explain to the Senate how this is fair and how these tax increases will complete the main objective of the budget, which was supposed to be the creation of new jobs?

—The question is no more accurate in its subject matter than in the person to whom it was directed. It is wrong in its fundamental foundations and mis-conceived. First of all, tax as a percentage of GDP was not, in any event, going to go up as a result of this budget.
—He did not say anything about that.
—But he skilfully avoided the fact that there are major reductions in tax as well. He did not mislead; he just set out to create the wrong impression—fortunately, quite unsuccessfully.

PARA.TAB: I want, principally, to talk about jobs. I refer Senator Tierney mainly to the excellent contribution made by the Minister for Finance in the House of Representatives yesterday about the jobs issue. It said, quite clearly—and everybody but an economic illiterate would know—that the most important thing one can do in a budget with regard to jobs relates to the overall rate of economic growth.

This budget is designed to give an economic stimulus this year by increasing the deficit in a way that is responsible. It is providing a stimulus, which is what the country needs, while those opposite are proposing cuts. They are proposing to reduce the deficit, to reduce the fiscal stimulus and to reduce economic growth, which will inevitably reduce employment and increase unemployment—a consequence that everybody but an economic illiterate would know.

It is absolutely irresponsible to pretend that those opposite come in here concerned about equity, when they have two priorities. Their priorities are to slash spending, when everybody knows that the most significant redistributive action a government takes is how it spends money not how it raises money, and to make major cuts in outlays, which would be fundamentally regressive and unfair. They are also proposing to withdraw fiscal stimulus, which will slow the rate of economic growth and, as an inevitable consequence, increase unemployment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I note that the minister admits that stimulus has been created by a deficit increase. One wonders why it is going to be called the deficit reduction bill. I ask the minister again: how, really, is the government increasing taxes? I refer him again to the wine industry. He made an appalling mess of the answer the last time we questioned him about it. How can increased taxes such as this create new jobs, which was supposed to be an objective of the government's budget?
—I will just say two things and all the rest will be wasted. It is a deficit reduction strategy which is set out clearly in the budget. Why does Senator Tierney not get someone to read it for him?

—Over four years you can do more than one thing. We will try to get the budget written in smaller words and bigger letters next year. The other thing is that, with regard to the wine tax, nobody is suggesting that the overall level of outlays is going to go down. If Senator Tierney's wild misconception that there is going to be a loss of jobs in the wine industry should in any event be correct, it would only be because there was increased expenditure in another area of outlays, whether it be beer, soft drink, mineral water or whatever, so the net effect on jobs would be nil.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. The minister would be aware of press reports of direct talks between the government of Israel and the PLO and that Israel and the PLO are close to an agreement. What is the Australian government's assessment of the prospect for progress in the Middle East peace process?

—The government very warmly welcomes the reports that the Israelis and the Palestinians may be very close to agreement on a declaration of principles which would provide for the early transfer of power to Palestinian authority in much of the territory of the West Bank as well as the whole of Gaza.

PARA.TAB: While the agreement is yet to be formalised and a number of further details obviously are going to need to be elaborated, we do understand that the arrangements for the transfer of power may include, firstly, the transfer of authority from the Israeli civil administration to Palestinian control in Gaza and the West Bank town of Jericho; secondly, redeployment of the Israeli defence forces away from Palestinian population centres; thirdly, the principle of early empowerment being applied to most of the area of the West Bank, not just Jericho, providing initially for transfer of authority in the fields of health, education, welfare, tourism and culture; and, finally, elections for a Palestinian council to administer self-rule to be held at least nine months after the declaration of principles is implemented.

The issue of Jerusalem is expected to be placed on the agenda explicitly for negotiations on permanent status of the occupied territories, which will commence between two and three years after the signing of the declaration of principles. That is, of course, in accordance with the understandings reached at Madrid in 1991. According to these reports, there is also an expectation that Israel may announce its recognition of the Palestine Liberation Organisation, the PLO, which is a rather breathtaking breakthrough.

It is clear that there are now prospects for substantial movement in this forthcoming 11th round of bilateral negotiations commencing in Washington this week. A breakthrough in the Israel-Palestinian track of this order may also, of course, prove extremely useful in stimulating progress in the other bilateral tracks involving Lebanon, Syria and Jordan. We recognise that there are many groups in Israel, among the Palestinians and elsewhere, who are opposed to the kind of agreement that now appears in prospect.

There is obviously a long road ahead before a just and lasting peace can be secured in the Middle East, but certainly these reports suggest that the peace process is at last producing the seeds of a broadly acceptable agreement. I hope those groups on both sides of the argument who are opposed to or indicating hostility to this are large minded enough and large spirited enough to appreciate the historical opportunity that is now before people in the region, for the first time, really, to secure a lasting peace.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lees Sen M.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. The Treasurer commenced his budget speech by saying:

QUESTION.PARA: The greatest issue facing our nation is how to provide jobs for our fellow Australians.

In light of that statement, I ask the minister: will the government seriously consider the suggestion raised today by the ACTU to impose a surtax on those earning more than $75,000 a year or, alternatively, consider the Democrats' suggestion of a Medicare style levy to create a $1 billion fund to provide jobs for our fellow Australians?

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sure the government will look very carefully at all options that are suggested for job creation programs of one kind or another and the means to fund them. That remains, of course, an issue that is very much on the agenda and which we are going to have to confront when we get the report that has been commissioned by Mr Beazley on this whole issue. However, it is not something that I would envisage being further addressed in the context of this particular budget, obviously, because we do have in this budget a budget which contributes in its own responsible economic way to the achievement of exactly that goal.

PARA.TAB: The way in which it contributes to it is by creating a macro-economic environment which will be stable and perceived to be as such into the medium term through to 1996-97: an environment which will, in fact, guarantee the maintenance of a low inflation environment; above all, an environment which will maintain the existence of a low interest rate environment; and an economic environment which rides the growth that we are expecting to be injected back into the economy over that period in a way that will generate a very confident environment for investment and for the kinds of new economic activity—in particular export oriented activity—that are, at the end of the day, more than anything else absolutely crucial if we are to get unemployment back to reasonable and acceptable levels in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the minister for his answer and for what are some interesting theories. But is the minister really saying that, after 10 years, the government has no specific ideas or specific plans and that we are, in fact, going to wait another six to 12 months—or, indeed, a million Australians are going to wait another six to 12 months—before anything specific is done?

—I do not know where Senator Lees was for most of the last decade, but she may recall that we had hugely effective job creation—job growth—throughout most of that period, and it is only in the recessionary environment of the much more recent years that that situation has turned around. It is a situation that, as she ought to well know, is being experienced in common with every other developed economy in the world. We have to approach the solution to it not in a way that resorts to gimmicks or short-term solutions which may have some superficial appeal; we have to get the fundamentals of the Australian economy right.

PARA.TAB: Of course there are specific programs that one can contemplate. Of course, the training and skill programs that we are talking about—the education programs—are all in their own way designed to achieve a better working environment, a better job opportunity environment for the future. Similarly, the infrastructure spending that we have been injecting through One Nation and related programs has that effect. But, ultimately, at the end of the day, if we want to make a fundamental inroad into the employment and unemployment situation in this country, we have to do it through creating a sustainable growth environment marked by low inflation, low interest rates and an attractive environment for investment. That is exactly what we are creating; that is exactly why this budget remains the very responsible document that it is.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Science and Small Business. I understand that yesterday the minister hosted the eighth National Small Business Forum in Canberra, which was attended by representatives of the major small business organisations. Can the minister provide any information on government initiatives canvassed at the forum which are designed to ease some of the burdens associated with establishing and running a small business?
—I call the Minister for Science and Small Business.

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators—Ha, ha!

TALK.START.PARA: —I must say, Mr President, that it is again useful to note that those on the other side laugh their heads off at any mention of small business. They are not interested in any practical applications that can help small business. It is this government that has done more to help small business in a practical way. That is why the eighth National Small Business Forum—a forum initiated by this government—was very well attended by all the major national small business organisations. There were over 50 delegates and observers. We dealt in a practical way with a number of issues that the Small Business Forum itself raised.

PARA.TAB: One of the issues that small business has always raised in Australia is overregulation at federal, state and local government level. At the forum this government tabled a report by the ABS called Study of the workload placed on small businesses by government paperwork—a survey of 224 firms which confirmed that small businesses are facing an extra impost through the endless number of forms that they have to fill in.

We have announced a major program of what I would consider excellent micro-economic reform for the rest of this period of government to reduce the regulation at federal, state and local government levels. This has to be done cooperatively, of course, because the overwhelming amount of regulation that affects small business is in the local government area. However, we accept the fact that at the national level we have a responsibility to reduce this regulation. I commend the report to honourable senators opposite.

I inform those honourable senators opposite who care to listen that at the forum yesterday there was also tabled and circulated a report from the Institute of Chartered Accountants of Australia called The road to recovery: solutions for small business. Amongst other things, it dealt with equity issues, lack of finance and regulation.

TALK.START.PARA: —I'll bet it doesn't say to vote Labor next time.
—I would suggest that even Senator Vanstone may be interested in reading it because it gives very practical suggestions.
—Why don't you table it?
—It is freely available. I will arrange to get copies to Senator Tambling.
—What does it say about tax and superannuation?

—I would tell Senator Tambling what it says in a whole lot of areas if I had more than four minutes in which to answer this question. It made a number of very practical suggestions in the areas of equity and finance to small business, and it again identified the area of regulation. Senator Tambling might be interested to know that it identified simple things such as problems with the size of forms to be filled in.

PARA.TAB: Senator Tambling interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —If Senator Tambling wants to belittle the work of the Institute of Chartered Accountants, he can do so. I will be happy to tell the institute that he is not interested in its work.

PARA.TAB: In the time that I have available, I will speak about the interest the coalition has in small business. Last Sunday night an invitation was extended to the coalition to send a representative to attend a Small Business Coalition meeting and dinner. Nobody from the coalition bothered to turn up to that dinner, which indicates the interest of those opposite.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The minister's time has expired.

—Mr President, I have a supplementary question. I further ask the minister: based on the research papers that he refers to, where was the greatest burden of information having to be provided by small business? Was it at the local government, state government or federal government level? What sort of cooperation is he getting from those other levels of government for the sorts of initiatives he is planning?
—It is quite clear, on the information before the Small Business Forum, that the biggest area of regulation requirement is from local government.
—You said that before.

—If Senator Watson would stop shouting, perhaps people would hear. That is the major area. We will work cooperatively with the states and local government to reduce this level of unnecessary regulation required on small business. I would have thought that the coalition would be very supportive of removing this unnecessary regulation by federal, state, and particularly local government.
—You said it all before.
—All Senator Watson is doing is shouting, whingeing and whining; he is not showing an interest. If he had an interest, why did the coalition not accept the invitation and send a representative along?

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators—Time!

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Minister's time has expired. I will say when time has expired; I do not need assistance.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. In view of the government backdown last night on at least some of the tax increases, is the government now prepared to reconsider the increased taxes on wine which will reduce employment, investment and exports in the industry?
—Senator Troeth should see my previous answer.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The minister's answer is most unhelpful and will cause great concern in rural Australia. I would like to point out to the minister that since 1986, when sales tax on wine increased from 10 per cent to 20 per cent, 1,000 potential jobs in vineyards have been lost. Now that the government proposes to raise the sales tax from 20 per cent to 31 per cent—an increase of 55 per cent—does the minister concede that this will have a devastating effect on employment rates for men and women in rural and regional areas in the vicinity of vineyards? Could the Minister explain clearly the employment effects in the wine industry of this tax and how Mr Dawkins will assist this industry to export?

—It is very hard to work out how that is a supplementary question, but Senator Troeth is a new senator. If her colleagues had not been shouting so loudly, she would have heard me say earlier today to Senator Tierney that, to the extent that there is any impact in the wine industry, it must be because people are transferring their expenditure from wine to other beverages.
—Nobody believed you then and we don't now.

—If Senator Macdonald keeps opening his mouth, there will not be one person in Australia who does not know that he is ignorant. If there is any job consequence, quite clearly it will only be because of a transfer. If there is any loss of jobs in the wine industry—it is not Senator Troeth's job to come in here and spout what the industry says; she should think about it for herself, as she is entitled to—it will be compensated by new jobs in the parallel industries. The net effect of the tax on jobs will be nil.

—Has the attention of the Minister for Foreign Affairs been drawn to claims by the representatives of the Dalai Lama that China plans a huge migration of Chinese settlers into Tibet in the campaign of cultural genocide? As such moves would clearly be in breach of China's international human rights obligations, will the government protest in the strongest possible terms against their implementation? Has the government pressed the Chinese government to enter into earnest negotiations with the Dalai Lama as urged in the human rights report by the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade?

—I have seen reports alleging that the Chinese government has decided to move large numbers of ethnic Han settlers to Tibet to weaken support for Tibetan independence. The Australian Embassy in Beijing is constantly monitoring the human rights situation in Tibet, including this question of transmigration. It has not yet been in a position, however, to confirm those reports of large-scale population movements into Tibet.

PARA.TAB: We are disappointed that the Chinese government refused to allow the second Australian human rights delegation to visit Tibet some months ago. We are also disappointed that Australian Embassy officials have been restricted in their ability to visit Tibet to assess the situation there. With that kind of access, it is obviously not possible to confirm the truth or otherwise of these kinds of reports. However, if these reports are true, such actions by the Chinese government would be a breach of the rights of the people of Tibet to enjoy their cultural heritage, and Australia would make its grave concern known to the Chinese government.

Finally, we continue to believe that there would be very considerable value in the representatives of the People's Republic of China government and the Dalai Lama meeting, without excessively restrictive preconditions, to discuss the situation in Tibet with a view to resolving tensions there. That is a view that we have put a number of times to the Chinese authorities and will continue to press.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Is it a fact that the recently proposed extension of the fringe benefits tax now means that employers will be obligated to pay FBT on education and training fees paid for an employee?

—I will need to check the answer to that question. It is one properly directed to the minister representing the Treasurer. I do not have a brief on it and I do not carry the information around in my head, but I will be delighted to give the honourable senator an answer as soon as I can.
—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. If this is the case, is this not just another example of a government adding cost burdens to employers?
—I think the editorial is a little premature until we get the actual report.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Transport and Communications. I refer to last year's 9 December submission by the minister's department to caucus which predicted that the local manufacturing content of satellite pay TV reception equipment would be only 43 per cent, that imports of reception equipment would exceed $100 million per year and that printed circuit boards would be manufactured offshore. I ask the minister: has he yet been persuaded by industry representatives that pay TV printed circuit boards can be manufactured competitively in Australia along with all the components of reception equipment other than integrated circuit chips? Will the minister use the industry plan provisions of the Broadcasting Services Act to ensure that printed circuit boards for all pay TV reception equipment are manufactured here in Australia?

—The answer to the first part of Senator Bourne's question is that there is no question that Australian companies are perfectly capable of manufacturing this equipment, and to a very high standard. In fact, in just the last six months, we have seen some spectacular examples of Australian technology companies substantially and dramatically increasing their exports of this electronic equipment from Australia to overseas markets.

PARA.TAB: Australian companies are certainly able to do it, but the key question is whether they can do it at competitive prices. The reason I make that point is that Australian companies will certainly have to do that so that the Australian consumer is not unreasonably slugged with equipment which is dramatically more expensive. I reiterate that Australian companies have demonstrated that they can do this effectively.

The Broadcasting Services Act provides for industry conditions to be set as a licence condition. As Senator Bourne knows, those arrangements were agreed to in the Senate and put into the legislation. But that can be done only in a generic sense.

As I know Senator Bourne is also aware, because the Senate debated this matter at length, the digital standard can be set only after the allocation of the A and B licences. The conditions that apply to that, which were amended by the Democrats in the Senate, have brought the date forward by which that had to be done to a point where, if the A and B licensees do not agree to a standard by March next year, the minister can then set the standard. Once the A and B licensees have agreed on a digital standard—which is important in terms of the consumer protection involved in that measure to ensure that people are not having to choose between more than one set of technology—the specific industry conditions can then be set, because the manufacturers will then know precisely what type of equipment it is that they have to manufacture.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I refer to yet another government lie on tax increases. Why has the government been trying to disguise its proposed diesel fuel rebate tax as an administration fee and been stating, as Senate Schacht did recently, that legislation will not be necessary? Does the government intend to introduce legislation to implement this new tax, in a separate tax bill, on the diesel fuel rebate scheme, and is such a draft bill already in circulation?
—I have not got a brief on the situation with regard to any legislation concerning that matter. I will look into it and get an answer for Senator Ferguson in due course.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I find it staggering that the government does not even know what it is doing in this regard. I ask the minister: is the government now considering this matter because of the constitutional status that was raised last Thursday at the estimates committee, or did Senate Schacht mislead the estimates committee in stating that it was not necessary? Would the minister be prepared to table any legal advice in relation to the proper and lawful way to introduce this administration fee?
—I am not so sure that that was a supplementary question. If the minister representing the Treasurer wants to answer the question, I will allow him to do so.
—I will add any information the Treasurer might wish to add to that question to the information I have previously indicated I will supply.

—My question is directed to the Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services. The minister would be aware that the Australian film Black River has won an international award, the Grande Prix Opera Screen, for 1993. Can the minister advise whether or not the film Black River received any government support?

—I am sure that all of the people employed in the film industry will note the derision with which questions about it are raised. Apparently they are not proper jobs if they are not jobs the opposition approves of; but they are still workers, they are still jobs.

PARA.TAB: The Commonwealth Government provided financial support for the production of the Australian film Black River. We provided a total of $1.1 million, which was the total production budget for the film. It was produced as part of Film Australia's national interest program and it also received investment funds from the Australian Film Finance Corporation.

Senators from Victoria would be interested to know, though some of them are talking instead of listening, that there was a significant useful contribution from the Victorian government to this matter. Development money for the film was provided by Film Victoria. I welcome that as an example of the very useful role that can be played, and sometimes is played, in partnership and cooperation between the state and Commonwealth governments in cultural areas in general and film in particular. I welcome that and hope that we can have more of it.

The very significant fact is that the success of Black River is a significant indication of the continuation of the success of Australian films, particularly low budget Australian films, which have won international acclaim. The film industry is doing very successfully on a number of fronts and it is creating a large number of jobs which I think most interested people would welcome. The other important thing about Black River that Australians would welcome is that it has provided an all too rare opportunity for the talent of Aboriginal performers to be seen in the film industry—a medium which has mass appeal but in which Aboriginals have had little access so far and about which the government is introducing programs to try to overcome that lack of access.

The film is a controversial one because it confronts the issue of Aboriginal deaths in custody. It is filmed against the background of outback Australian locations. It is very important that if we are going to develop a film industry of contemporary relevance, we are prepared to take on those sorts of culturally important themes, however difficult they are, particularly in this international year of indigenous people.

We all welcome the success of Black River as we welcomed the success of The Piano, Strictly Ballroom and other Australian prize winning films, and we welcome the success of the industry and the jobs it is creating.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs. The minister may be aware that the Aboriginal Legal Service executive officer, Rob Riley, in Perth is reported to have admitted that the ALS lodged a full page advertisement which appeared in the West Australian on Wednesday, 11 August, which urged people to join a public meeting and march in Perth on 13 August. —I address my question to the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women. I note that earlier this year the minister launched the publication Women and Media at a national industry forum held by the national working party on the portrayal of women in the media. Can the minister inform us of what progress has been made regarding the portrayal of women in the media?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen The Hon R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —In 1988 the government established a national working party to achieve a fairer and more accurate portrayal of women in the media. On 1 July 1993 the national working party's work culminated in a national forum on the portrayal of women in the media. At that forum I was able to launch the women in media kit—
—Really exciting news.
—Yes, I think it is very good news because most of those opposite do not know it. I am happy to tell them that that kit conveyed documented evidence—
—How long ago is this?

—If Senator Vanstone had been listening, she would know that it was 1 July this year. That kit conveyed the measured evidence that the portrayal of women in the media is still very insufficient in amount and content—to the point where I think all women in this place, if not all honourable senators, should be concerned. I am interested that opposition senators do not seem to be concerned about it.

PARA.TAB: I draw Senator Vanstone's attention to a report in the Advertiser about this launch because I think it reflects very much the challenge that faces us when we are looking at the portrayal of women in the media. The report in the Advertiser was written two days after the event. Amongst other things, the editor, Peter Blunden, had this to say about the portrayal of women in the media and, in particular, in the Advertiser:

ANSWER.PARA: . . . recent news stories in The Advertiser reflected the diversity—

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order. Mr President, I draw your attention to the position on the Notice Paper of ministerial statements, which this government does not see fit to use very often. The opposition would be very interested to hear the minister tell us what was done back on 1 July. She obviously has just got in touch with it herself; she has only caught up with it. We would like to hear about it in some depth, but not at question time. Mr President, would you ask the minister to defer her statement until the time set aside for ministerial statements?
—Order! Senator Newman is quite aware that that is not a point of order.

—I do know what I am talking about, but Senator Newman does not. She was not there; she did not come. The opposition has just discovered women, so it will take it some time to catch up. Mr Blunden said:

ANSWER.PARA: . . . recent news stories in The Advertiser reflected the diversity of women's lives. These included coverage of sexual harassment figures, drug use at menopause, home birthing, de facto rights, older women ending marriages and teenage girls' attitudes to romance.

I say to Mr Blunden, editor of the Advertiser, that that is not what I, or any women, would call a comprehensive coverage of the diversity of women's lives. I am shocked that the opposition does not come in here and object to the Advertiser thinking that that is a comprehensive coverage of what women in the media are about.

PARA.TAB: The Advertiser deserves acknowledgment for one thing: its coverage of women's sports is better than that of any other paper in the country. That coverage takes up about 5 per cent of the columns in the newspaper. That is not sufficient either. I give credit to the Advertiser for its sports pages. But if Peter Blunden thinks that litany is a coverage of the diversity of women's lives, we certainly have a challenge ahead of us in the portrayal of women in the media.

I notice that the opposition has recently discovered the importance of women when it comes to votes. It certainly objected to it in the last election. It was only in July last year that Dr Hewson was saying that the opposition did not have a policy about women so much as a social equity policy with implications for women. In the last election the women of Australia did not want to be implicated by Dr Hewson. The opposition has since realised the error of its ways. If it were sensible, it would listen to what this government has discovered about the portrayal of women in the media. It is an issue that should enjoy the support of the opposition.

Members of the opposition are now saying that we need a bipartisan approach to issues such as violence against women. I would be much more interested to see them supporting the government in a better portrayal of women in the media than hearing their carping criticism today, which suggests that they are not serious about it.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. I refer Senator Gareth Evans to yesterday's outrageous attack on Australian business by the ACTU President, Mr Martin Ferguson, when he described Australian business as being characterised by laziness, negativity and cowardice. He said that the performance of Australian business has been truly regrettable. He described the lack of export initiatives as a national disgrace. He then went on to say that `Australia's future could well be the horror stories of Los Angeles, with alienated kids murdering each other in their hundreds, with drive-by shootings, with a vast criminal subculture turning the streets into battle zones'. Does the government support the president of its accord partner?

—I am not sure that I would employ quite the same language as Martin Ferguson did in describing Australian business. But, equally, I think it is a fair comment that Australian business has not yet fully risen to the opportunities that are now presented by the present domestic economic environment and the external export environment that are available to it.

PARA.TAB: There has been a change in business culture in this country since the mid-1980s onward, and that is reflected in a very considerable increase in focus on export potential and export performance. It has been reflected in the very encouraging figures that we continue to read each month in the balance of payments with regard to continuing export manufactures performance, particularly on the side of elaborately transformed manufactures.

It is the case that a number of small to medium sized businesses, the so-called McKinsey 700, have demonstrated the kind of flair and positive outlook—not the negativism and conservatism—that are necessary if this country is to prosper. Equally, it is the case, both for a number of much larger businesses and for the remainder of the 6,000 businesses that are referred to in that same McKinsey report, that there has not yet been a grasping of that export potential; there has not yet been an assimilation and absorption of that as export culture; there has not yet been a full enough willingness to grasp the opportunities that are available to business through things like the export market development grants scheme, the international trade enhancement scheme and other things of that kind which are designed to help Australian companies that want to get out there and compete with the rest of them.

It is the case that a heck of a lot more change needs to be inculcated into management practices, into training and into awareness about the scope and potential for getting out there and producing much better returns than Australian business is producing at the moment. That is a very fair criticism that is made of much of Australian business. Incidentally, it is a fair criticism that is made of a number of business organisations, and I am not persuaded that they have, between them, contributed a great deal of value in terms of themselves changing this particular culture and producing this new environment in the business community that we all so badly want.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. In view of the words of the minister's predecessor with regard to the increase in manufacturing exports from this country, particularly in the motor car industry, does the minister support Australian business being described as lazy, cowardly and a national disgrace or not? It is a simple yes or no answer.
—A junior Perry Mason—yes or no.
—That is a pretty tough cross-examination that I have just been exposed to. I think I sufficiently answered the question in my original reply. I do not need to repeat it.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Health. Could the minister inform the Senate as to the number of sporting organisations which have applied to continue their tobacco sponsorships under the Tobacco Advertising Prohibition Act up until 1995. How many exemptions has the minister granted under the same act for events of international significance?
—How did you get on last night?

—I was busy in my office last night. I do not know where Senator Alston was. Mr President, I would have thought that tobacco advertising was a serious issue in Australia and when Senator Childs asks a question he is at least entitled to an answer. The question was about the number of companies which have sought to continue to advertise after this year and, indeed, up until 1996. If the conditions of section 21 of the act are met, it amounts to quite a few companies. So far, 155 section 21 defences have been lodged, which is actually a very large number of organisations. It shows the reason why some of these defences were put in in the first place.

PARA.TAB: After the end of 1995 some advertising can continue. Under section 18 the Minister for Health can exempt certain Australian sporting and cultural events that have international significance. So far, four applications of that kind have been received and, so far, I have approved three of them. These were: the Telecom Rally Australia which took place in Western Australia a couple of months ago; the Australian Ladies Masters Golf Tournament in Queensland—I might say, I am still getting arguments on that because the decisions are so detailed and so strict as to limit the size of advertising on the bibs that the caddies wear in the tournament, but that decision has been made nonetheless—and the Adelaide Grand Prix, which I signed an exemption for last week and which I think is now well and truly established on the international scene.

The other application that I have received is under consideration, and in accordance with that legislation is therefore confidential. I cannot as yet reveal any details of it. Discreet acknowledgments of assistance or support are permitted, provided they comply with the regulations made under the act. The truth is that the regulations made under the act are so restrictive and so strict that I think even the hardest of those in the lobbies who have sought to strengthen bans on tobacco advertising would have to be pleased.

Point of sale advertising is permitted under the Commonwealth legislation and that will apply in states and territories without relevant laws, although I understand from talking with the states and territories that those without them are rapidly complying by introducing their own. When I can make available details of the fourth one which is under consideration for an exemption, I shall do so.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Communications—dare I ask. How many inquiries about the availability of SBS television services have been received by the SBS from rural regions of Western Australia by comparison to other states? Is it not true that existing facilities can be used for the transmission to rural Western Australia? Exactly what time frame does the federal government have for SBS to fulfil its charter obligations of being available to all Australians both of ethnic and non-ethnic origin? And why can they not have immediate access?
—That question involves a quite detailed answer. I have no information on it to provide to Senator Knowles now. I will provide it to her at a later time.

—Did the Minister for Family Services and the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women read the speeches made by the opposition leader and the deputy leader on violence against women? If so, are they in line with government policy and programs on violence against women?

—Yes, the two speeches by Drs Hewson and Wooldridge have been drawn to my attention and I have read them. It is very encouraging to see that the opposition now recognises the fundamental issues that concern women and the importance of the issue involving violence against women. I have to say it is about time, and I welcome that support.

PARA.TAB: The opposition might care to read those speeches very clearly too, because there is a difference between those speeches. I would recommend Dr Wooldridge's analysis of the causes of domestic violence over that of his leader, Dr Hewson. Dr Wooldridge resists the temptation to come up with simplistic or sloganeering kinds of causes.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is no sloganeering.

—There is a difference as I read them. I note that in this place Senator Newman has tried to account for domestic violence, or at least the causes of it, in a simplistic way. I refer Senator Newman to Dr Wooldridge's speech, which covers a very complex and grave matter in a very thoughtful way. But the point is that the opposition is now prepared to argue for bipartisan support on this absolutely vital issue of concern to women, and I welcome that very much.
—We have always had that.
—If we have already had it, why is it such a big public announcement at this stage? I think it is an important change in opposition policy, and I very much welcome it.

PARA.TAB: I have to say that the opposition's points of view are very much consistent with this government's policies. In relation to the approach we have had of a national view about domestic violence, the government has put this matter on the political agenda, has brought this issue out in public and has worked very closely with the states through the relevant ministers' meetings, particularly the Attorneys-General, to see that we have now got in place—and I believe in all states, but there may be still one or two not on board—legislation for the portability of protection orders. That is an issue of grave concern and indeed has been raised by senators in this place from time to time.

We have also seen the change of legislation that allows police to seize guns from any person against whom a protection order has been issued. We know that those require the states' cooperation and, as I understand the opposition's policy, it is entirely in support of the government's policies on this issue. So I can see that we will have a very strong voice from this Senate to continue the campaign of working with the states to see the necessary changes, because most of the changes that are needed are at state level.

I welcome very much the opposition's changes in this area. All of us know that, despite these changes, there still is not an assurance in this community that women who go in fear of violent partners can be guaranteed that protection. Although we have dealt with some issues—for example, the portability of orders—we know that women are not guaranteed that protection and I sincerely hope we will continue to take the steps we need to take.

I welcome the opposition's support. I think a bipartisan voice on this vital to women issue will only benefit the steps that the government intends to take. We have seen announcements by the Prime Minister during the election campaign. Those initiatives by the government, which are promises from the election that we have implemented already, will only be the better for this new approach from the opposition.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask that Senator Crowley table the speeches to which she was referring. Presumably, she will not claim that they are confidential.
—Order! This is a matter for the minister. Will you table the speeches you were quoting from?
—If the opposition wishes me to provide copies of Dr Hewson's and Dr Wooldridge's speeches, I can do it.
—Table them.
—I do not have them here; I was not quoting from them.
—Mr President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.
—Order! On three separate occasions today interjectors on my left said to ministers directly, `You are a disgrace'. It will not be tolerated again.
—Well, they are.
—I beg your pardon?
—A senator on the other side was heard to say, `Well, they are'. I think she should be obliged to withdraw it.
—I did not see who it was.

—I have an answer to a question that Senator Ferguson asked earlier today. I am pleased to advise the Senate that it is a question that should have been directed to my colleague the minister responsible for customs because the matter is being dealt with within that portfolio, not within the Treasury. Nevertheless, I can advise Senator Ferguson that there is legislation currently being drafted by the Office of Parliamentary Counsel on instruction from the Australian Customs Service and the question should properly have been asked there.

PARA.TAB: There are two bills. One will be called the Diesel Fuel (Excise Duty Rebate Administration Charge) Bill 1993 and the other will be the Diesel Fuel (Customs Duty Rebate Administration Charge) Bill 1993. These administration charge bills respectively impose an administration charge on a person in respect of the processing of an application for a rebate for excise duty or customs duty as the case may be. I am advised that the rate of the charge is one per cent of the amount of rebate payable.
The bills are taxing bills. Two bills are being prepared because the diesel fuel rebate covers excise and customs duties, and having two bills avoids any chance of invalidity.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why don't you take the same approach to the deficit reduction bill?

—If Senator Alston does not understand the issues, he should not speak. I am simply saying to Senator Ferguson that that is the information that is available and it is a matter not being dealt with within the Department of the Treasury nor any area which I represent, but I am happy to provide the information to him.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Australian Broadcasting Corporation: Ms Pamela Bornhorst

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday Senator Boswell asked me a question regarding the position of Ms Pamela Bornhorst, a 7.30 Report presenter from the ABC, and I advised Senator Boswell that I would seek further information as to whether the minister for communications had been advised about this proposed action. He was not advised, as I was not advised. Indeed, it was not appropriate or necessary for the minister to be advised. The ABC, as I said yesterday, is an independent statutory body. The government has no authority to intervene in its staffing matters and for the government to do so could effectively compromise the editorial position of the broadcaster.

PARA.TAB: The most important information which I provide—and it is particularly important in respect of a notice of motion in the name of Senator Parer—is that the matter of Ms Bornhorst's position is currently before the Industrial Relations Commission, and no doubt there will be a resolution to that issue in the commission.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I take this opportunity to table a legal advice, the subject of which is the constitutionality of the Taxation (Deficit Reduction) Bill, prepared by Mr Dennis Rose QC, Chief General Counsel for the Attorney-General's Department. I seek leave to make a short statement in relation to that advice.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am indebted to the Senate. The document makes clear that the bill in the form in which it is now before the Senate is constitutional in accordance with principles which not only have been long applied by parliamentary counsel but also have clear High Court authority. It is not possible to summarise in short compass the detail of this advice and I do not seek to do so, except to make these two points. First of all, it is a bill properly characterised as one `dealing with taxation' and it is also a bill properly characterised as one `dealing with the imposition of taxation'. What it is not is a bill `imposing taxation'. These distinctions are familiar ones in the High Court case law and those points are made clearly by Mr Rose.

PARA.TAB: The second point as to the content of the advice is the question as to whether the bill, if passed, would be `a law dealing with more than one subject of taxation'. This question is also addressed in a way that makes it clear that there would be no adverse consequences to flow constitutionally if the bill were to be passed in its present form. The advice must speak for itself, and it does so.

The advice was prepared in anticipation of the Senate committee inquiry proceeding, but it does reflect in its content the nature of the principles that were applied throughout the drafting exercise by parliamentary counsel and advice given by the Attorney-General's Department during that drafting process.

The document is tabled as a matter of courtesy rather than obligation to assist the Senate, and in particular the proposed Senate committee in its consideration of the constitutionality of this issue. Hopefully, tabling it now will expedite that process of consideration. I indicate now that we will not be opposing—not that we have much choice in the matter—the reference to the committee. I would expect that to go through formally in a few moments time, without any further debate or seeking leave to make a further contribution, I hasten to add.

I do take this opportunity, however, finally to indicate that while the government will not be opposing the reference of the whole issue to a Senate committee, and while I am now tabling this 13-page very detailed advice, the government will be opposing the motion, if pursued, requiring us to table drafting instructions and other related documents, notice of which has been given by Senator Hill. The grounds for the government's opposition to this are strong grounds of public interest immunity, and they are ones that the government would certainly insist upon for good reason which, if the occasion arises, I will be happy to spell out. I think it is inappropriate to do so now.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—Mr President, I wish to make a short statement relating to the advice tabled by the minister. While I respect the advice and integrity of Mr Rose, I think it must be remembered that he was asked to do a job defending the government in its handling of this particular issue. So we would hardly expect a decision from the Attorney-General's office contrary to what the government has put forward. What the government now proposes is to treat these sorts of issues as issues in a non-taxing bill. We disagree with that particular philosophy because, in our view, that non-taxing bill certainly contains taxing elements.

PARA.TAB: I find it rather strange that this advice conflicts with an answer that has just been handed down in this place in relation to the matter previously raised by my colleague Senator Ferguson. In that case the government has two particular bills to meet the constitutional requirements, namely, a tax raising bill and a bill concerned with the administrative aspects.

The real point at issue is that the government is trying to treat this as a non-tax raising bill to enable it to add a string of issues associated with this particular feature. I put it to the Senate that this is contrary to the constitution. The government is seeking to avoid some very fundamental constitutional issues through a very unsatisfactory device called tacking. I think this is deplorable. The government cannot have it both ways. It can produce either a bill which basically relates to administrative issues and, as such, can be amended, or a bill involving the raising of revenue. I think it is a very shabby exercise; it is a very devious means of getting around what are justifiable constitutional restraints. I suggest that the minister refer the issue back to the Attorney-General's Department.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ferguson Sen A.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services (Senator McMullan), in response to a question without notice asked by Senator Ferguson this day, relating to a proposed tax on the rebate on diesel fuel.

SPEECH.PARA: While I will concede that the question I put today to the minister representing the Treasurer is a matter for customs, I find it absolutely amazing that he had no idea as to whether a new taxation bill was being drafted or had been drafted and put into circulation. The one thing that Senator McMullan did not say in his answer was when the decision was taken to draft this bill. I find the conclusion of question time to be a pretty unusual time for the government to announce that it is introducing a new tax measure.

PARA.TAB: I asked when it was decided to draft this new tax bill because of what was said at estimates last Thursday night about the implementation of this new so-called administrative fee to pay for the administrative costs of the diesel fuel rebate scheme. It was established by the officers and by Senator Schacht from the program performance statements for the inland revenue that the administrative and salary expenses totalled $16.5 million in 1992-93. The inland revenue officers estimated that one-quarter to one-third of this related to the diesel fuel rebate scheme; that is, somewhere between $4.1 million and $5.5 million could be attributed to the administration of that scheme. It was also determined that, because an expected amount of just over $1 billion is to be rebated to eligible diesel fuel users, the income from this fee would be just in excess of $10 million.

At the estimates Senator Schacht argued that not all the expenses may have been included in the program performance statements. Our advice is that any other significant expenditure would have to appear as a separate line in the budget papers. There was no other line in the budget papers. Therefore, we could assume that all administrative expenses are included in the program performance statements, especially as at that estimates committee hearing Senator Schacht specifically stated that there are no costs incurred in administering the scheme outside of the inland revenue program.

If it were the case that this fee had to be put into place by the implementation of a new tax, I would like to know why at that time on this important matter—and, remember, it is a line in the budget, so surely some legal advice should have been sought prior to the estimates hearing; long before the hearing last Thursday when I asked these questions as to whether the fee would be constitutionally legal—Senator Schacht, in his answer to my questions and also to questions from Senator Hill, said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . that it is not necessary for legislation . . .

I believe that until that time it was decided that this would be a backdoor tax that nobody knew of. The Government would be able to implement a new tax which would bring in increased revenue to the government without the introduction of any legislation. It was not until it was pointed out that the matter would be unconstitutional if it brought more revenue in to the government than was to be expended in administration and salaries, that this government then decided that it had better do something about it. It hastily sought to draft a new tax bill in order that this fee could be brought into place to bring in the expected $10 million of revenue for this government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Scandalous.

—I think it is scandalous and I think that the people of Australia ought to know that once again this government is introducing a new tax which will hit those people who can afford it the least—those in rural and regional Australia, those in nursing homes, the people involved in our mining industry and all those people who have been able to get a diesel fuel rebate because of the nature of their production and their industry.

PARA.TAB: I do not know why last Thursday we were unable to get an honest answer from the Minister—namely, that legislation was to be prepared or even that he did not know. But I certainly believe that as far as the legality of a fee is concerned, the department or the minister should have received legal advice saying whether this fee could be implemented without introducing new tax legislation.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Science and Small Business and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make a few comments in relation to Senator Ferguson's motion. If Senator Ferguson reads the transcript of that long estimates committee hearing last Thursday, he will note that although I conceded that the inland revenue section of the Australian Customs Service has administration costs and administers the diesel fuel rebate scheme, I clearly indicated that other areas would have to be investigated. I promised Senator Ferguson that by the time the estimates committee met the following Thursday I would get a more detailed breakdown. The issues he raised about the administration costs I conceded were quite relevant and to the point, as was the question about how we get the $9 million to $10 million figure when he and I were estimating on the back of a envelope the division of the inland revenue section. I certainly made it clear to the department that I want that complete breakdown.
—Why hasn't the decision been made now?

—Senator Ferguson should let me finish. The breakdown will be provided to him by Thursday, if not beforehand. The information of that breakdown was based on work done by the Audit Office. I wanted all of that double checked.

PARA.TAB: Senator Ferguson raised the issue, quite rightly, that one does not need legislation if it is an administrative fee, but the administration fee cannot exceed the cost of administration. I also conceded that if there were any doubt, there would have to be legislation. There is now to be legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the doubt been established already?

—Whether there is doubt or not, as a result of the discussion on Thursday night my view was that there ought to be legislation. If there is to be any argument—and I do not think there will be—I am told the figures which are being prepared but which have not been completed will show that the administration fee of one per cent is equivalent to the administrative cost, which is $9 million to $10 million. Irrespective of allowing for any variation from time to time, I think it is absolutely correct that legislation be put to the parliament so that it is beyond doubt.

PARA.TAB: This administration fee of between $9 million and $10 million per annum relates to the diesel rebate scheme. For 1993-94 the pay-out under the scheme is estimated at over $1 billion to people in Australia in all the eligible areas. We are not talking about a massive charge at one per cent raising $9 million or $10 million on a pay-out to eligible people of over $1 billion. When this was introduced by the Fraser government, the estimated cost was around $200 million.

I point out, as I did in the estimates committee, that since that time there have been a number of appeals to the AAT over the issue of eligibility. I am told that on almost every occasion over the last decade the AAT has upheld the appeal against the government over extending the eligibility. So now you have people who are eligible for the diesel rebate scheme who are in no way connected with primary production or the mining industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —But they are off-road.

—They are off-road. I found a case the other day where a senior, very well paid public servant in Canberra is eligible for the rebate scheme because he has a diesel heater in his house. This person is earning well over $60,000 or $70,000 per annum and is able to claim under the diesel rebate scheme because he has a diesel heater at home. I do not think that even the Fraser Government, when it introduced this scheme, designed it so that well paid public servants in Canberra, by the fact of their having a diesel heater, could claim the rebate.

PARA.TAB: That was a decision of the AAT that has consistently widened the application of the scheme. We think it is not unreasonable that the one per cent administrative fee—

TALK.START.PARA: —One per cent tax.
—Yes, it is a tax. It will be covered by legislation. Therefore, all the doubts that Senator Ferguson raised will be dealt with. I will give him the information again on Thursday.

—I want to address the very same answer that Senator Ferguson moved to take note of, to which Senator Schacht responded. I will not go deeply into the eligibility issue. However, even Senator Schacht will admit that when this diesel fuel rebate came in in 1957 exemption certificates applied for diesel used off-road. Unfortunately, he has to accept that this rebate of $1 billion to the mining and rural industries, et cetera, is no help to industry; it is simply a rebate for fuel that is used off-road.

PARA.TAB: I tend to agree with Senator Schacht that it might not seem right that a highly paid public servant, in Canberra especially, gets a refund on diesel fuel that he uses on heating, but unfortunately we have to accept that it is used off-road. Unless that criterion is changed, I am afraid that the rebate has to be given to him.

Senator Schacht gave us figures about the cost of administration behind the introduction of the one per cent administration fee. Of course, we could go back to the old system—I know that the Fraser Government changed it—of bringing in the levy and taking it out again. There might have been a few dodgers, but a lot of claims come in that are eligible to go out. They do not go out because a lot of farmers and other operators forget to claim.

When Senator Schacht gives us this information on how he arrived at the one per cent administration fee, I want him to tell us whether the government or the Treasury has allowed for the interest that accumulates on the global figure that is kept in Treasury for roughly two months. From my experience, the turnaround time for rebate claims is, on average, two months. That is what I believe, and I might be wrong. Working on the basis that that amount is held by Treasury for two months and using the present interest rate of about six per cent per annum, interest of one per cent would accrue for that time. Is Treasury allowing for that one per cent increase per two months—or six per cent per year—for which that global figure belonging to the eligible users is held in Treasury? If it is not making allowance for that, it is really costing the user two per cent. I would like Senator Schacht to answer that question in time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I also support my colleague Senator Ferguson and congratulate him on the work he did at the estimates committee last week. What he did was unfold another one of the sneaky actions of this current government. I state that, being a farmer, I do have a personal interest in this matter; I am very concerned about the diesel fuel rebate.

PARA.TAB: This issue is not really about the breakdown of those figures—although it will be interesting to get those figures—it is about this government not knowing what it was doing, introducing a tax under what is called an administrative fee and actually putting this tax in place. It is a tax that has no relevance to the administration fee. That has been proved by the very able questioning of Senator Ferguson last week.

Senator Schacht and his government deserve to be condemned for the way they have tried to sneak this matter through and for not being honest about it. Senator Schacht did not know the answers to some of the questions, but I bet some of the people behind the scenes would know the answers. The government has already moved to tax the wine industry out of existence. It is now attacking those people who are legitimately eligible for the diesel fuel rebate.

Maybe Senator Schacht should get some of his history right while he is on the job, because the diesel fuel rebate scheme, in fact, started back in 1957. Mr Fraser was not in power then. If my memory serves me right, Mr Menzies was the Prime Minister of Australia at that time.

In 1983, or thereabouts, the government once again tried to sneak away the value of the diesel fuel rebate by indexing it. It did not index the rebate. There was a period of time when the full fuel excise was not being refunded to those people who were eligible for the diesel fuel rebate. This just highlights very clearly the hypocrisy and deceit in the way that this government is currently going about doing its business.

I can assure the government that when this bill comes before this place it will be well and truly scrutinised. If this tax has to come into place—and I certainly will not be supporting it—it should relate only to the administration fee and should be put in such a way that it cannot be increased. I can see what Senator McMullan, Senator Schacht and Senator Gareth Evans will be doing next year; they will moving to increase this tax to two per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh!

—Senator Schacht leaves this chamber with deceit written all around him; and knowing the dishonest way that this has been put before this chamber and the way that it was handled in the other place, if I were in his position I too would be leaving with my tail between my legs. Again I support my colleague Senator Ferguson and congratulate him for exposing this dirty, tricky, little, slimy scheme.
—I do not want to continue to be seen as carping, but I regard the statement that the minister is surrounded by deceit as unparliamentary.

—I will very briefly say that it seems to me that Senator Schacht has again attempted to mislead the Senate in what he said to Senator Ferguson and Senator Hill in relation to this matter. It was a very practical, useful and well attended conference.
