PARA.TAB: With reference to the report presented to the then Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services (Mr Staples) in July 1991, entitled "A Question of Balance, Report on the Future of Drug Evaluation in Australia" by Professor Peter Baume:
(1) How many of the 164 recommendations made by Professor Baume have been fully implemented.
(2) For those which have been fully implemented, when did this occur.
(3) For those which have not been fully implemented, why has full implementation not been completed.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (2) Professor Baume set exacting timelines with 13 recommendations to be implemented "immediately" or "as soon as possible". Of the remainder 85 had key dates set for implementation. There were 12 dates set through the period 1 September 1991 to 1 July 1993. Most of the deadlines were met, but some were late due to special circumstances:

(i) In Recommendation 51 it was required that all applications for new chemical entities should contain draft patient information by 1 January 1992. This date was not met because agreement had not been reached between the Therapeutic Goods Administration (TGA), the pharmaceutical industry and consumer organisations on what should be included as patient information. This was settled in due course which allowed the key date for the provision of patient information (Recommendation 50, 1 January 1993) to be met.

(ii) A review of the Clinical Trial Notification Scheme was required under Recommendation 103 and should have been commenced in May 1992 with a report available by November 1992. There were difficulties experienced in establishing a suitable review committee. The committee subsequently submitted its report in May 1993.

(iii) Advice was required from the National Health and Medical Research Council (NHMRC) by 1 January 1992 in relation to the import of antibiotics under Recommendation 124. The advice was not received until March 1992 due to the schedule of NHMRC meetings.

(iv) Performance agreements for senior medical staff, Recommendation 153, were not introduced until December 1992 due to delays across the Australian Public Service in introducing performance agreements for medical officers.

(3) Some of the recommendations have not been fully implemented because the key dates have not yet been reached. Recommendation 2 has a reference to 1996 and Recommendation 50 refers to 1 January 2002.
A number of recommendations have not yet been implemented due to special circumstances:

(i) In Recommendation 114 it was proposed that a change in the Therapeutic Goods Act 1989 was required in relation to the statutory duty of care. Parliamentary Counsel advised that the implementation of the recommendation would be impractical.(ii) Recommendation 145 and Recommendation 151 depend on the development of a strategic management plan. This was delayed by the National Manager, TGA until the newly appointed Head of the Drug Evaluation Branch of the TGA took up his position during March 1993. Draft guidelines for the strategic plan are presently being considered by a management/union consultative group which had been set up in relation to the Baume Report implementation.

(iii) The organisation and structure of TGA and the Drug Evaluation Branch are covered in Recommendations 146 and 148. These issues are now being considered following the appointment of the Head of the Drug Evaluation Branch. Some restructuring has taken place.

(iv) In Recommendation 162 it was proposed that meetings of groups of external evaluators should be held once or twice a year for inservice training. Contact is maintained with individual external evaluators but because of the resources involved it has not been possible to hold the meetings proposed within the Report.

The major recommendations of the Baume review relate to the evaluation process for new chemical entities and other drug products, access to drugs by seriously ill patients, clinical trials, individual access to unapproved drugs, and international harmonisation in drug regulation. All of the recommendations related to these activities are implemented and TGA is meeting the new performance standards required under legislation.

(4) To which individual or body will the Foundation report.
(5) Will the Foundation present an annual report on its progress.
(6) What steps have been taken by the Government to develop the Museum of Australia.
(7) Which body or individual will develop and administer the development and implementation of the national collection of Australian art and heritage.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been advised that the answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) Considerable discussion has taken place with key interest groups and individuals since the Government announced before the election its intention to establish the Foundation. There will be further liaison with interested parties prior to the Foundation coming into operation in early 1994.

(2) The terms of reference for the Foundation are still being refined. The Foundation will work in partnership with universities, museums and local government, as well as community organisations and individuals on projects designed to extend Australians understanding of our own nation
(3) The Board will be appointed by me to oversight the operations and direction of the Foundation.
(4) The Foundation will report to me in my capacity as Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services.
(5) Annual progress reports will be presented to me and included in my Department's annual report.

(6) The Government established the National Museum of Australia through the National Museum of Australia Act 1980. In 1992-93 $5.607 million was appropriated for the running of the Museum and this figure has been increased to $6.465 million in 1993-94. This includes additional funding for an expansion of the Museum's operations at the Old Parliament House and for the investigation and procurement of non-government capital funding sources for the Museum.

In addition, the Government has made an in principle commitment to $26 million over four years to develop buildings for the National Museum of Australia at the Yarramundi site. Of this money, $3 million will be appropriated during 1993-1994 for development of detailed design and documentation for the building project.
The total appropriation for the National Museum for 1993-94 is therefore $9.465 million.

(7) Development and administration of a network to record details of culturally significant collections of Australian art and heritage will be undertaken jointly by a Heritage Collections Committee and the Australian Cultural Development Office of the Department of Arts and Administrative Services. The Heritage Collections Committee is being established under the auspices of the Cultural Ministers Council. The Committee will comprise representatives from Commonwealth, State and Territory Governments and the cultural sector and will be chaired by the Commonwealth. The Australian Cultural Development Office will provide the Secretariat.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Touring Program for the Visual Arts, Crafts and Museums

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services, upon notice, on 20 July 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) When will a touring program for the visual arts, crafts and museums be introduced.
(2) Which body or individual will establish and administer the selection criteria for the program.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been advised that the answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) A touring program for the visual arts, crafts and museums will be operating by the end of 1993.
(2) Guidelines for the Program are in the process of being developed through my Department. An advisory panel will administer the selection criteria for the program.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services, upon notice, on 20 July 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) How much of the $0.4 million promised to enhance programs monitoring indirect government assistance to the cultural sector through the tax system will be spent in the 1993-94 financial year.
(2) How much of this money will be spent during 1993-96.
(3) What body or individual will administer these monitoring programs.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been advised that the answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) The new program has the two main elements of education and monitoring. In 1993-94, a total of $148,000 will be spent on the program. It is estimated that approximately half of this amount will be spent on the monitoring component of the program.
(2) $148,000 has been allocated for each of four years for the full Cultural Taxation Incentives Education and Monitoring Program. Thus a total of $0.444 million will be spent in 1993-96.
(3) The program will be administered by my department's Australian Cultural Development Office, which has responsibility for the administration of cultural tax incentive programs.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services, upon notice, on 20 July 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) When will the Government introduce a scheme whereby owners of buildings listed in Commonwealth, Territory or State heritage registers can claim taxation rebates for approved private conservation work on these buildings.
(2) What measures have been taken by the Australian Heritage Commission and other heritage agencies to develop the approval process for the scheme.
(3) How will revenue forgone under this scheme be capped at $2 million per annum.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been advised that the answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Commonwealth will introduce a taxation incentive scheme for approved heritage conservation works on properties listed in Commonwealth, State and Territory registers in 1993-94.

(2) The Australian Heritage Commission has contributed to the development of the scheme through its membership of a working party formed by the Australian Cultural Development Office in my Department. Treasury and the Australian Taxation Office were also represented on the working party which consulted State and Territory heritage agencies about the scheme's parameters and approval process. The scheme will be administered by the Australian Cultural Development Office with the assistance of the Australian Heritage Commission and State and Territory heritage agencies.

(3) The Taxation Incentive Scheme for Approved Heritage Conservation Works will be capped at $1.9 million per year in revenue forgone through a competitive selection process. The cap was reduced to provide an element for administration of the scheme. Once selected into the scheme applicants will be able to claim a 20% rebate after successfully completing the conservation works for which approval was given.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services, upon notice, on 20 July 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) What measures have been taken by the Government to establish a Bequests Program.
(2) When will tax deductibility and a capital gains tax exemption for bequests be introduced.
(3) When will artists be allowed to participate in the Taxation Incentives for the Arts Scheme in respect of their trading stock.
(4) How will revenue forgone under this scheme be capped at $2 million per annum.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been advised that the answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Government has agreed to a proposal put forward by myself and the Treasurer for new tax incentives (tax deductibility and capital gains tax exemption) to encourage bequests of significant cultural items to the nation. The Bequests Program will operate as a supplement to the existing Taxation Incentives for the Arts (TIA) Scheme.
(2) The program will commence in 1993-94 once relevant administrative arrangements, including amendments to the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936, have been made.

(3) Under both the TIA Scheme and the Bequests Program, artists and creators will be able to make donations of their own works if these are from their personal collections. While donations of trading stock by artists will continue not to attract a market value deduction, guidelines will be developed clarifying the distinction between personal collections and trading stock.

(4) The Bequests Program will be capped at $2 million per year in revenue forgone through a competitive selection process. For the purposes of the cap, the amount of the deduction in respect of each bequest will be assessed and fixed at the time of agreement. Revenue forgone will be estimated at a notional rate of 40% of the value of the deduction. The cap will include the revenue forgone under both concessions—the deduction and the capital gains tax exemption.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services, upon notice, on 20 July 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) What measures has the Government taken to review the compact disk (CD) rental policy and to examine the effects of CD rentals on the rights of artists and sound recording copyright owners.
(2) If a review body has been established, what is its membership and terms of reference.
(3) Do any of the States or Territories have any role or input into this review process.
(4) Will the Music Industry Advisory Council play any role in this review.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been advised that the answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1 & 2) A working group has been established to examine options for the Government. It consists of representatives of my Department and the Attorney-General's Department. The terms of reference are the Trade-related Aspects of Intellectual Property Rights (TRIPS) treaty decisions and the effects of CD rentals on rights of artists and sound recording copyright owners.
(3) It is intended that the review process will involve consultation with all relevant and affected groups, including States and Territories. A consultant may be engaged to assist.
(4) The recent report of the Music Industry Advisory Council (MIAC) on these issues will be considered by the working group.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services, upon notice, on 20 July 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) When was the Music Industry Advisory Council established.
(2) Who are the members of the council.
(3) Who chairs the council.
(4) How often does the council formally meet and when will it next meet.
(5) What are the terms of reference for the council.
(6) To whom or what body does the council report.
(7) What are the mechanisms by which the council reports.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been advised that the answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Music Industry Advisory Council was established in 1992.
(2) The 11 members of the council are as follows:
Mr Emmanuel Candi
Ms Deborah Conway
Mr Ross Gengos
Mr Peter Hebbes
Mr Robert Hirst
Mr Gregory Innes
Mr Tony King
Ms Joy McKean
Mr Kim Wilson
Mr John Woodruff, and
Mr Simon Young
The Department of the Arts and Administrative Services and the Department of Industry, Technology and Regional Development are observers on the Council.
(3) Mr Kim Wilson chairs the Council.
(4) The Council normally meets about six times a year. In 1992-93 the Council met five times, including the inaugural meeting in November. The next meeting is scheduled for September 1993.

(5) I understand that the Council has no set terms of reference but its objectives are to examine and advise the Government on issues relevant to the Australian music industry. The Council's principal task in its first year of operation was to review the extent of industry adjustment to the Government's decision to deregulate record imports. The Council is also undertaking work into the issues of copyright, performers' rights, exports, employment, technology and live music.

(7) The Council provides written reports on the issues it has considered to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Regional Development. The reports are circulated to other relevant portfolios. These reports are based on the work of members, discussions with industry groups, and expert research that has been commissioned by the Council.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services, upon notice, on 20 July 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) When will the review of the issue of copyright on music recordings begin.
(2) Who or what bodies will complete this review.
(3) How will the review be conducted.
(4) Are there any terms of reference for the review; if so, what are they.
(5) Is there a date by which the review will be completed.
(6) To whom will the review body report.
(7) Will the findings of the review be made public.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been advised that the answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) The review has already commenced.
(2 & 3) The Music Industry Advisory Council (MIAC) has reported to Government on relevant issues, including industry views. An expert consultant has been engaged to conduct the review.
(4) The terms of reference are to consider copyright on music recordings taking into account local competition conditions and prices, world trends in copyright trade and the MIAC recommendations.
(5) By the end of the year.
(6) To the Government.
(7) It is expected that the findings of the review will be made public.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services, upon notice, on 20 July 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) What measures have been taken by the Government to expand industry assistance schemes.
(2) How much of the $3.5 million promised by the Government in extra assistance to the Australian Film Commission (AFC) will be spent in the 1993-94 financial year
(3) When will the remainder of the funds in extra assistance to the AFC be spent.
(4) What steps have been taken by the Government to develop a program of assistance to enable Australian publishers to better position themselves in the Asia-Pacific region.
(5) Has the review of the role and accountability of copyright collecting agencies, to be conducted jointly by the Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services and the Attorney General, begun.
(6) How will the review be conducted.
(7) Which individuals or bodies will assist the Ministers with the review.
(8) Are there any terms of reference for the review; if so, what are they.
(9) Is there any date by which a report will be completed.
(10) Will the findings of the review be made public.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been advised that the answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) An important new Government program has been announced in the Budget to improve access by the cultural industries to existing industry assistance programs.

My Department has consulted with key Commonwealth service providers and is consulting with State and Territory Arts Ministries to develop a number of elements to the new program. It will include the provision of an information program on existing industry extension schemes, the development of sector specific packages within these schemes and the centralised collection of cultural industry data.
(3) $1.0m in each of the financial years 1994-95, 1995-96 and 1996-97.

(4) The development of an export market development package for the publishing industry is a key element of the industry extension program. The program of assistance to enable publishers to better position themselves in the Asia-Pacific region is in a preliminary stage of development. To date, discussions have been held with AUSTRADE, the Australian Book Publishers Association and other representatives of the publishing industry

(6) & (7) An expert in the area of copyright and collecting societies will be appointed to conduct the review. A working group of officers of the Department of the Arts and Administrative Services and the Attorney-General's Department will implement the outcome of the review.
(8) The terms of reference are in the process of being drafted.
(9) Completion should be by the end of the year.
(10) Yes

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services, upon notice, on 20 July 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) Will the Festival of Youth be established by 30 June 1994.
(2) What activities will be involved in the Festival of Youth.
(3) Who or what body is going to run the Festival of Youth.
(4) How will young artists be selected to participate in the Festival.
(5) What are the selection criteria for inclusion in the Festival.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been advised that the answer to the honourable senator's question is:

PARA.TAB: (1) Yes.
(2) A number of proposals have been received from various organisations and in order to encompass the best mix of activities I intend to convene a round table conference.
(3) Following the conference a decision will be made on how the Festival will be run.
(4) & (5) Selection procedures will be subject to guidelines to be drawn up after the conference.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services, upon notice, on 20 July 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) Which body or individual will investigate the possibility of raising the status of the National Aboriginal and Islander Skills Development Association.
(2) What measures have been taken to begin this investigation.
(3) What percentage and grade of representation of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people will there be on the committees of `Playing Australia' and the Visual Arts Touring Program.
(4) What measures have been taken to re-establish the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Arts Board of the Australia Council.
(5) When will the board be re-established.
(6) How will the board be selected.
(7) What will be the function of the board.

(8) Which body or individual will conduct a feasibility study into the viability of establishing in Darwin an Asia-Pacific Biennale of Indigenous Arts and Sciences and when will the study be completed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been advised that the answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) A small expert Committee will be appointed for this purpose.
(2) Preliminary work has been undertaken to develop terms of reference for the Committee and to settle its membership.

(3) It is proposed to appoint a representative of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people to the Committee of `Playing Australia' in the near future. A committee has yet to be appointed to the Visual Arts Touring Program but it is likely to include at least one representative of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people.
(4) The Australia Council and the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission have been consulted on membership of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Board of the Australia Council.
(5) The appointments will be announced as soon as these consultations and the necessary appointments procedures are completed.

(6) Criteria for the Board members are that they will be of Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander origin, the majority to consist of practising artists, with at least one community interest representative.

(7) The function of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Arts Board is to assist Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people to revive and maintain their cultural practices through visual arts/crafts, performing arts, literature and multiform arts (community festivals and ceremonies) and international programs.

(8) A consultant will be appointed to conduct the feasibility study. The consultant will be required to consult with representatives of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander community, the Office of Northern Development, the Northern Territory Government and the Northern Territory arts community in preparation for the conduct of the feasibility study. The report is to be completed by March 1994.
